message: Interested in hearing a brainstorm from folks here about what a project like that could provide to vim users, what features would you want?
The codebase running that site hasn't seen an update in years, and the mailing list is nothing but spam and crickets going back even farther
So I've been helping out with the task of taking the code behind djangopackages.com and making it more usable for other collections of packages, and vim extensions came to mind.
The more I looked into the state of the backend that was driving http://www.vim.org/scripts/ the more I realized vim could really use a modern community hub around its extension
seems that vim is growing in popularity and there are some great projects out there like vimcasts and vimgolf
I'm proposing an online directory of extensions based on the packaginator codebase
But I could see a site with a well organized list of various stuff be useful
like a section devoted to syntax files, a section devoted to vcs , etc, etc
To be honest, I find the djangopakages design and presentation of packages to be utterly confusing when it comes to using quality packages.

+1 on having a new portal for Vim scripts.  That said, could it be done as something that's a compliment to vim.org/scripts?  Not that it's that great, but there's a lot of infrastructure built around it (the GitHub mirror, for example).

Discoverability would be key, as would some social aspect (what to other developers like me use).  It'd also be nice to be able to create packages of scripts ("here's my text editing must-haves") and/or link to your existing .vim repos and have it scrape those to figure out what you use.

Note that Vim.org is also the portal through which Bram collects donations for the children in Uganda. Anything that diverts traffic away from that cause could be considered to be stealing food from orphans. I think any new hub for the Vim community should be sensitive to the politics of charityware.
Im a huge fan of being able to create packages like @tswicegood mentioned.

@nelstrom what I'm talking about so far is just a barely born idea - I think it could completely embrace vim's karmic goals.  In fact I think a fresher design can highlight the charity aspect even more.  It looks like http://iccf-holland.org/ is about the same vintage and design as vim.org - maybe as a team of website builders we can help there in parallel (just brainstorming).  I had already sent an email to the contact listed for tech maintenance for vim.org, but have not heard back.  But would certainly be willing to float this idea by Bram himself if he is reachable.
@tswicegood I also like the ideas of scraping posted .vim setups to look for common .vimrc lines, and popular bundles

when I was using Notepad++ I apreciated this page (list of plugins) http://bit.ly/idJKxV It's simple but had all the info I needed to get up and running and find the plugins I needed, might be interesting.
+1 for the social aspect. There are many duplicate scripts, and it would be nice to know which ones people like.

@dz constructive feedback on how to improve the layout and usage would be useful.  This project would share a codebase with Djangopackages, but doens't mean that layouts can't be changed, or features added/extended

@tswicegood from my reading of the vim-scripts.org project, they were born of a similar idea.  They scrape vim.org to generate their github mirror.  I think for sure any representation of a package should link to both vim.org/scripts and vim-scripts.org
I'm also suggesting that this entire project be open source and community driven

What other community plugin/module sites are out there that people might want to draw inspiration from? On the Ruby side there is http://rubygems.org/ which is fairly simple in implantation (other than the flashy design) and includes basic info on owners, versions, stats, and links.
http://vim.wikia.com/wiki/Vim_Tips_Wiki is much better than http://vim.org/scripts but it's still hard to find info you want
I guess no one here has seen vim-scripts.org? There are tools to leverage it for script installs
@morganiangoose I have for sure seen vim-scripts.org, in fact their scraper project would be integral to what I'm talking about
it would be awesome
